title.narrative: DRT Capacity building of ELNHAs in DRR

description.narrative:
DRT - The project title: Capacity building of Local and national humanitarian actors in disaster risk reduction, preparedness and Integration The 1-year project aims to strengthen capacities of local and national humanitarian actors in disaster risk reduction,preparedness and management. To be implemented in six districts of Agago, Arua, Lamwo, Kabong, Koboko and Kotido as well as nationalengagements at Kampala level
Project purpose: To strengthen the humanitarian system in Uganda and to promotesustainable comprehensive humanitarian response and disaster risk reduction, integration, skills, education and learning in Uganda which is accessible andsustainable to local humanitarian actors especially at the District level.
The identified problemto be addressed by the project: In the recent HuCoca and the DRT conducted needs assessment it is clear that local governments have glaring capacity gaps to plan and implement disaster risk reduction and management. The most important of these capacitygaps pertain to weak and non-functional systems and structures for DRRM. Specifically, the proposed project will focus on filling the following gaps:
i) Non-functional and/ orvery weak District Disaster Management Committees (DDMCs). ii) Lack of updated (if any) DRR plans. iii) Lack of connectedness between humanitarian and development planning at local government levels - local governments do not have enough space to reflect and planhumanitarian strategies and are often constrained to the implementation of plans/programs from the national level. iv) Learning andknowledge management is non-existent to the extent that only few staff have received humanitarian training, and implementation doesnot feed into any learning processes for both state and non-state actors. Approach for Implementation The overall capacity development approach that DRT proposes to use is process facilitation using participatory methods. This approach uses hands-on skills building focussing on the application of tools andmethods. DRT shall support the target district local governments and selected non-state actors through the different stages of project implementation, from defining/ clarifying capacity development goals, and the specific actions that will lead to achievement of those goals; and together review progress periodically until the review and learning processes at the end of the project.
Key activities: i) To profile and harmonise understanding of the efforts with the Local Governments ii) Strengthen capacities of local governments and selected interested LNHAs in humanitarian situational assessment, sector specific risks and vulnerability mapping and integration of DRRM in development plans and programmes iii) Support LNHAs to utilize the humanitarianintegration model to mainstream disasters into development plans and programmes iv) Facilitate 2 week quarterly exchange learning programs with humanitarian actors. 12 persons (3 per quarter) shall benefit from this mentoring action. These persons shallbe selected from the 6 districts together with the LG officers and ELNHA partners. v) Explore key learning resources and establish a humanitarian knowledge and learning platform such as a humanitarian resource center Primary beneficiaries: The projectwill primarily focus on local humanitarian actors based at the districts. The will include both state and non-state local actors. These will be the local government officials, specifically heads of departments/ sectors from each of the six districts, theDDMC, the sub county disaster management committee (SC DMC), Parish Disaster Management Committees (PDMCs), and the Disaster Policy Committees where they exist.

participating-org.narrative:
The organisation was founded in 1997 by 3 persons (2 of them now deceased) Charles Lwanga Ntale and Ibanda Igaga are still alive. Mr. Ibanda resigned from the BOD for other duties. Charles is now a trustee of the organisation. The organisation was founded to influence pro-poor policies and programmes with the view of eradicating poverty particularly chronic poverty. The organisation first registered as a company limited by guarantee but later (in 2007) registered as a non-governmental organisation. The focus of the organisation was never on gender but through research activities conducted particularly the Uganda Participatory Assessment process, we were able to understand that gender is a cause for vulnerability and therefore we started to mainstream all our work. 2. ACHIEVEMENTS What have been the principal results in the past three years that contribute to significant, structural, sustained and positive improvement in the lives of men, women, girls and boys suffering from poverty, injustice, insecurity and exclusion? Our work on Chronic poverty analysis resulted into the formation of a Uganda social protection platform which we facilitated for now 10 years. Our engagement on the same has made government to approve a social protection process andimplementation of Expanding Social Protection Programme. 3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE Mission: To influence pro-poor policies and programmes through research, evidence based engagement and institutional capacity building and learning Institutional objectives: i) To increase access to and utilisation of high quality poverty evidence-based research by Government Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs) and non-state development actors in the development and implementation of pro-policies by end of 2021 (2). ii) Increased abilities of partners (CSOs, vibrant communities,and state actors) to inluence and implement pro-poor policies and programs by 2021 (3). iii) To increase access and uptake of Uganda#s economic and livelihood development strategies to the chronically poor by 2021 (4). iv) To increase transparency and accountability practices in governance processes by state and non-state actors at National and Local Levels by 2021 Field(s) of activity: DRT operates under 4 thematic areas: a) Governance and Transparency (GAT) b) Social Policy and Human Development (SPHD) c) Economic Policy and Livelihoods (EPL) d) Institutional Capacity Building and Institutional Development (CBID) Geographically DRT operates in the entire country benefiting Government and Non-state actors focusing on poverty reduction, the poor vulnerable persons in the country 4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING Analyse the environment in which the organisation works? Who are the other relevant social actors, including governmentand business, and what roles do they play? ' In this context, what is unique about the position of the organisation?
The environment under which we operate is worrying. Development practitioners are shifting focus from Poverty reduction (PEAP, 1997-2004) to #economic transformation# and wealth creation (NDP <(>&<)> Vision 2020). Poverty levels have reduced from 56.4% (1993) to 19.7% (2013). This is a wonderful picture but considering the fact that vulnerability has also increased from 33.4% to 43.3% in thesame period provides concern. Adding the poorest and the vulnerable population mean that 63% of the population is not in good position. The discovery of oil raises expectations and fears of misuse of this resource. Uganda#s population is increasing ata fast rate and the increasing burden of youth unemployment, inequality is high for North, North East and Eastern regions. There is an increasingthreat of natural and man-made disasters in the country (Conflicts, floods, landslides, lightening). The lackof systematic institutional planning for risks and disasters at national and LG levels makes the situation very fragile.
